The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. Policy makers, epidemiological modelers, and health researchers all require up-to-date data on the pandemic and relevant public behavior, ideally at fine spatial and temporal resolution. The COVIDcast API is our attempt to fill this need: Operational since April 2020, it provides open access to both traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity, such as signals extracted from deidentified medical claims data, massive online surveys, cell phone mobility data, and internet search trends. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The COVIDcast API also tracks all revisions to historical data, allowing modelers to account for the frequent revisions and backfill that are common for many public health data sources. All of the data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making

In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the classical sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation. We also discuss the relation between our model and the theory of tropical geometry. This paper is a first step toward a deeper understanding of the relation between tropical geometry and the theory of dynamical systems. We hope that this paper will stimulate further research in this direction.

Our findings have implications for climate-smart agriculture and the role of perennial grasslands in mitigating climate change. We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems. We show that the saddle-node bifurcation is a generic feature of the dynamics of this network, and we discuss the implications of this result for the study of chemical networks in thermodynamic environments. We also discuss the implications of our results for the study of the dynamics of chemical networks in general. We believe that our results are of interest to a broad audience of scientists working in the fields of chemical reaction dynamics, chemical reaction networks, and thermodynamics. We hope that our work will inspire further research in these fields.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid global warming, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000,000 y. The cause of the current warming is still under debate. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt global warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma during a glacial period. We show that the global warming event was accompanied by a major perturbation of the carbon cycle. The perturbation was linked to an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean, which likely enhanced thermocline stratification and nutrient fluxes. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced tropical forest loss in Indonesia by 33% from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification may be a useful tool for reducing deforestation in oil palm, but it is not a panacea. We also show that the RSPO’s certification system is not a good proxy for forest loss in oil palm plantations. We recommend that the RSPO develop a more accurate and transparent system for measuring forest loss in certified plantations. This would allow the RSPO to better inform its members and the public about the effectiveness of certification in reducing tropical deforestation. Vertebrate sex determination is a complex process that determines the sex of an individual before birth. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with multiple sex determination loci, sex is determined by a sex ratio-dependent mechanism, which is called polygenic sex determination (PSD). In this study, we investigate the effects of PSD on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where one female-determining allele and one male-determining allele interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes: females, males, intersexes, and hermaphrodites. We find that PSD in M. mbenjii produces an interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation resulting in modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits. The modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by PSD provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Siphonophores are pelagic colonial cnidarians that use specialized tentacle structures armed with nematocysts to capture prey. These tentacles are the only structures used for prey capture, and are therefore considered the “arms” of the siphonophore. Siphonophore tentacles are highly specialized, with each tentacle arm having a specific prey-capture function. This specialization is a key feature of siphonophores, and is thought to be an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophore tentacles have strong evolutionary associations with prey type, and that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentacles and their nematocysts. Our findings help build a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification via morphological evolution. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. The evolution of the human hand is a key area of hominin research. The fossil record for the hominin lineage between 800,000 and 1.8 My old is relatively poor, and the oldest known hominin hand fossils are incomplete. We report the discovery of a nearly complete hominin hand from the Middle Pleistocene of East Africa. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which converts serine to glycine and a folate-derived one-carbon unit. We show that SHMT inhibition is effective in colon cancer, and that a cancer cell-line screen reveals that B-cell lines are particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. We also show that formate, a substrate of the SHMT enzyme, rescues cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Deforestation is a major driver of biodiversity loss and climate change, but it is also a threat to people’s livelihoods and food security. In this study, we show that deforestation can affect people’s diets and vitamin A status. We found that deforestation in rural Tanzania led to a reduction in fruit and vegetable consumption and thus vitamin A adequacy of diets. Conversely, we found that forest fragmentation led to an increase in fruit and vegetable consumption and dietary vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the need to consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals. Modern farm machinery has greatly increased agricultural productivity, but the increase in vehicle weight has also led to higher risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
